unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Congressional Approval
question_text:
Last month, a pollster found that a sample proportion of $48\%$ of the national population approve of their congressional representative.
A $99\%$ confidence interval was constructed on this data with a $5\%$ margin of error. Suppose instead that a $90\%$ confidence interval was constructed on this same sample.
This $90\%$ confidence interval will have a margin of error of about
solution:
This problem tests your ability to know the formula for margin of error and solve algebraically to find the sample size with the original $99\%$ interval. Use the following equation, with the corresponding variables:

$$m=z^{*} \sqrt{\dfrac{p^{*}(1-p^{*})}{n}}$$

$m = \text{margin of error} = 5\%$
$p = 0.48$
$z^{*} = 2.576$ from the standard normal table

$$n=\dfrac{(z^*)^2\cdot p^* (1-p^*)}{m^2}$$

$$n=\dfrac{(2.576)^2 \cdot (0.48)(1-0.48)}{0.05^2}$$

$$n=662.516$$

Solve for sample size to get $n = 663$.

Then find the margin of error with the new $z$ of $1.645$ by using the same equation above for our $90\%$ confidence interval:

$$m=z^{*} \sqrt{\dfrac{p^{*}(1-p^{*})}{n}}$$

$$m=1.645 \sqrt{\dfrac{0.48(1-0.48)}{663}}$$

$$m=0.03192\cdot 100\%$$

$$m=3.192\%$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
